end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In the case of absorbing diffusion, similar to Tweedie-τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ leaping method in Section D.2, we can use Theorem 1 and Eq. 2.9 to simplify Eq. D.12, which results in

ps|teuler,i⁢(xsi|𝒙t)={σ⁢(t)⁢e−σ¯⁢(t)1−e−σ¯⁢(t)⁢(t−s)⁢p0⁢(xsi|𝒙tUM),if ⁢xsi≠[M],xti=[M]1−σ⁢(t)⁢e−σ¯⁢(t)1−e−σ¯⁢(t)⁢(t−s),if ⁢xsi=[M],xti=[M]δxsi⁢xti,xti≠[M].superscriptsubscript𝑝conditional𝑠𝑡euler𝑖conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡cases𝜎𝑡superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡1superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡𝑡𝑠subscript𝑝0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑡UMformulae-sequenceif superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]M1𝜎𝑡superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡1superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡𝑡𝑠formulae-sequenceif superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]Msubscript𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]Mp_{s|t}^{\text{euler},i}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\begin{cases}\sigma(t)\frac{e% ^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}(t-s)p_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^% {\textrm{UM}}),&\text{if }x_{s}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]\\ 1-\sigma(t)\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}(t-s),&\text{if % }x_{s}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]\\ \delta_{x_{s}^{i}x_{t}^{i}},&x_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}].\\ \end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT euler , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ( italic_t ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t - italic_s ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 - italic_σ ( italic_t ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t - italic_s ) , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] . end_CELL end_ROW (D.13)

In practice, we also use cθ⁢(𝒙t)⁢[i,xsi]subscript𝑐𝜃subscript𝒙𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖c_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})[i,x_{s}^{i}]italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) [ italic_i , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] to approximate the true conditional distribution p0⁢(xsi|𝒙tUM)subscript𝑝0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑡UMp_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) when sampling from Eq. D.13.

D.4 Equivalence of Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping and Euler method under log-linear noise schedule

By comparing Eq. D.8 and Eq. D.13, we observe that both the Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping and Euler methods can be interpreted similarly:

  • •

    If xtisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an unmasked token, keep it unchanged, i.e., xsi=xtisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖x_{s}^{i}=x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  • •

    If xtisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a masked token, first determine whether it will be unmasked with a probability ψ⁢(t,s)𝜓𝑡𝑠\psi(t,s)italic_ψ ( italic_t , italic_s ). If it is to be unmasked, then sample xsisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖x_{s}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from p0⁢(xsi|𝒙tUM)subscript𝑝0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑡UMp_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

The only difference lies in the analytic form of ψ⁢(t,s)𝜓𝑡𝑠\psi(t,s)italic_ψ ( italic_t , italic_s ). For the two methods, according to Eqs. D.8 and D.13, their corresponding ψ⁢(t,s)𝜓𝑡𝑠\psi(t,s)italic_ψ ( italic_t , italic_s ) are given as follows:

ψtweedie⁢(t,s)=e−σ¯⁢(s)−e−σ¯⁢(t)1−e−σ¯⁢(t),superscript𝜓tweedie𝑡𝑠superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑠superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡1superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡\displaystyle\psi^{\text{tweedie}}(t,s)=\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}-e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}},italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_s ) = divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (D.14)
ψeuler⁢(t,s)=σ⁢(t)⁢e−σ¯⁢(t)1−e−σ¯⁢(t)⁢(t−s).superscript𝜓euler𝑡𝑠𝜎𝑡superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡1superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡𝑡𝑠\displaystyle\psi^{\text{euler}}(t,s)=\sigma(t)\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e% ^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}(t-s).italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT euler end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_s ) = italic_σ ( italic_t ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t - italic_s ) . (D.15)

In general cases, these two expressions are not equivalent. However, if we choose a log-linear noise schedule σ¯⁢(t)=1−log⁡(1−(1−ϵ)⁢t)¯𝜎𝑡111italic-ϵ𝑡\bar{\sigma}(t)=1-\log\left(1-(1-\epsilon)t\right)over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) = 1 - roman_log ( 1 - ( 1 - italic_ϵ ) italic_t ), both Eq. D.15 and Eq. D.14 can be simplified to the same form ψ⁢(t,s)𝜓𝑡𝑠\psi(t,s)italic_ψ ( italic_t , italic_s ) as follows:

ψ⁢(t,s)=t−st,𝜓𝑡𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡\psi(t,s)=\frac{t-s}{t},italic_ψ ( italic_t , italic_s ) = divide start_ARG italic_t - italic_s end_ARG start_ARG italic_t end_ARG , (D.16)

which shows that these two sampling methods are equivalent under a log-linear noise schedule.

D.5 Discuss on the expectation of NFEs

In this part, we show that given the noise schedule σ⁢(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t)italic_σ ( italic_t ) and a set of time steps {t0=0,⋯,tn=T}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡00⋯subscript𝑡𝑛𝑇\{t_{0}=0,\cdots,t_{n}=T\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , ⋯ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T }, the NFEs can be treated as a random variable with a calculable expected value for both Euler method and Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping method.

Let l𝑙litalic_l denote the length of the generated sequence and Nk∈{0,⋯,l}subscript𝑁𝑘0⋯𝑙N_{k}\in\{0,\cdots,l\}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ { 0 , ⋯ , italic_l } denote the number of dimensions that 𝒙𝒙{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x changed in [tk−1,tk)subscript𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑡𝑘[t_{k-1},t_{k})[ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Without loss of generality, we first consider the unconditional generation case where l=d𝑙𝑑l=ditalic_l = italic_d. The NFEs, E-NFEs, and Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be expressed as

NFEs⁢(n)=∑k=1n𝕀⁢(Nk≠0),NFEs𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝕀subscript𝑁𝑘0\text{NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathbb{I}(N_{k}\neq 0),NFEs ( italic_n ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0 ) , (D.17)
E-NFEs⁢(n)=∑k=1n𝔼⁢[𝕀⁢(Nk≠0)]=∑k=1nP⁢(Nk≠0),E-NFEs𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝔼delimited-[]𝕀subscript𝑁𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝑃subscript𝑁𝑘0\text{E-NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{I}(N_{k}\neq 0)]=\sum_{k=1}^% {n}P(N_{k}\neq 0),E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ blackboard_I ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0 ) ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0 ) , (D.18)
Nk=∑i=1d𝕀⁢(xtk−1i≠[M],xtki=[M]).subscript𝑁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑𝕀formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘𝑖delimited-[]MN_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\mathbb{I}(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[% \textbf{M}]).italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) . (D.19)

Furthermore, we note that the d𝑑ditalic_d dimensions are independent. According to Eqs. D.8 and D.13, the probability ps|t⋅,i⁢([M]|𝒙t)superscriptsubscript𝑝conditional𝑠𝑡⋅𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msubscript𝒙𝑡p_{s|t}^{\cdot,i}([\textbf{M}]|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ M ] | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) depends only on time and xtisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT while independent of the other dimensions of 𝒙tsubscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, ps|t⋅,i⁢([M]|𝒙t)=ps|t⋅,i⁢([M]|xti)superscriptsubscript𝑝conditional𝑠𝑡⋅𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msubscript𝒙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝conditional𝑠𝑡⋅𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖p_{s|t}^{\cdot,i}([\textbf{M}]|{\bm{x}}_{t})=p_{s|t}^{\cdot,i}([\textbf{M}]|x_% {t}^{i})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ M ] | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Therefore, whether a token changes from masked to unmasked is independent across the d𝑑ditalic_d dimensions333The independence applies to whether a token changes from masked to unmasked. However, the specific unmasked token a masked token changes to depends on other dimensions.:

p⁢(𝕀⁢(xs1=[M]),⋯,𝕀⁢(xsd=[M])|𝕀⁢(xt1=[M]),⋯,𝕀⁢(xtd=[M]))𝑝𝕀superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠1delimited-[]M⋯conditional𝕀superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑑delimited-[]M𝕀superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡1delimited-[]M⋯𝕀superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑑delimited-[]M\displaystyle p\left(\mathbb{I}(x_{s}^{1}=[\textbf{M}]),\cdots,\mathbb{I}(x_{s% }^{d}=[\textbf{M}])|\mathbb{I}(x_{t}^{1}=[\textbf{M}]),\cdots,\mathbb{I}(x_{t}% ^{d}=[\textbf{M}])\right)italic_p ( blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) , ⋯ , blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) | blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) , ⋯ , blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) ) (D.20)
=\displaystyle== ∏i=1dp⁢(𝕀⁢(xsi=[M])|𝕀⁢(xti=[M])).superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑑𝑝conditional𝕀superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖delimited-[]M𝕀superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]M\displaystyle\prod_{i=1}^{d}p\left(\mathbb{I}(x_{s}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])|\mathbb{% I}(x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])\right).∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) | blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) ) . (D.21)

Since 𝒙Tsubscript𝒙𝑇{\bm{x}}_{T}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consists entirely of masked tokens with probability one, each dimension of 𝕀⁢(xtk−1i≠[M],xtki=[M])𝕀formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘𝑖delimited-[]M\mathbb{I}(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) is independent. Consequently, Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows a binomial distribution with parameters d𝑑ditalic_d and rksubscript𝑟𝑘r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as Nk∼Binomial⁢(d,rk)similar-tosubscript𝑁𝑘Binomial𝑑subscript𝑟𝑘N_{k}\sim\text{Binomial}(d,r_{k})italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Binomial ( italic_d , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where rk=p⁢(xtk−1i≠[M],xtki=[M])subscript𝑟𝑘𝑝formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘𝑖delimited-[]Mr_{k}=p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) represents the probability that xisuperscript𝑥𝑖x^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes within the interval [tk−1,tk)subscript𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑡𝑘[t_{k-1},t_{k})[ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in each dimension. Therefore, we can further simplify Eq. D.18:

E-NFEs⁢(n)=∑k=1nP⁢(Nk≠0)=∑k=1n(1−(1−rk)d).E-NFEs𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝑃subscript𝑁𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛1superscript1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑑\text{E-NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}P(N_{k}\neq 0)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(1-(1-r_{k})^{d}).E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0 ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - ( 1 - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (D.22)

By definition of rksubscript𝑟𝑘r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and property of absorbing diffusion:

rksubscript𝑟𝑘\displaystyle r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =p⁢(xtk−1i≠[M],xtki=[M])absent𝑝formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘𝑖delimited-[]M\displaystyle=p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])= italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) (D.23)
=p⁢(xtk−1i≠[M]|xtki=[M])⁢∏j=k+1np⁢(xtj−1i=[M]|xtji=[M])⁢p⁢(xtni=[M])absent𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗𝑘1𝑛𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗𝑖delimited-[]M𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑛𝑖delimited-[]M\displaystyle=p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])% \prod_{j=k+1}^{n}p(x_{t_{j-1}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{j}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])p(x% _{t_{n}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])= italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) (D.24)
=(1−p⁢(xtk−1i=[M]|xtki=[M]))⁢∏j=k+1np⁢(xtj−1i=[M]|xtji=[M]).absent1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗𝑘1𝑛𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗𝑖delimited-[]M\displaystyle=\left(1-p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}% ])\right)\prod_{j=k+1}^{n}p(x_{t_{j-1}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{j}}^{i}=[% \textbf{M}]).= ( 1 - italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) ) ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) . (D.25)

Eq. D.25 can be determined given the sampling method and noise schedule.

For Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ -leaping, based on Eq. D.8, we can derive that:

p⁢(xtj−1i=[M]|xtji=[M])=1−e−σ¯⁢(tj−1)1−e−σ¯⁢(tj).𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗𝑖delimited-[]M1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗11superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗p(x_{t_{j-1}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{j}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])=\frac{1-e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t_{j-1})}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j})}}.italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) = divide start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (D.26)

Therefore, we can express rksubscript𝑟𝑘r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as

rk=(e−σ¯⁢(tk−1)−e−σ¯⁢(tk)1−e−σ¯⁢(tk))⁢∏j=k+1n(1−1−e−σ¯⁢(tj−1)1−e−σ¯⁢(tj))=e−σ¯⁢(tk−1)−e−σ¯⁢(tk)1−e−σ¯⁢(tn).subscript𝑟𝑘superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗𝑘1𝑛11superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗11superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑛r_{k}=(\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k-1})}-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k})}}{1-e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t_{k})}})\prod_{j=k+1}^{n}(1-\frac{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j-1})}}{1-e^{% -\bar{\sigma}(t_{j})}})=\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k-1})}-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k% })}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{n})}}.italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - For the Euler method, based on Eq. D.13, we can derive that:

p⁢(xtj−1i=[M]|xtji=[M])=1−σ⁢(tj)⁢e−σ¯⁢(tj)1−e−σ¯⁢(tj)⁢(tj−tj−1).𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑖conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑡𝑗𝑖delimited-[]M1𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗1p(x_{t_{j-1}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{j}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])=1-\sigma(t_{j})% \frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j})}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j})}}(t_{j}-t_{j-1}).italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) = 1 - italic_σ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (D.28)
rk=(σ⁢(tk)⁢e−σ¯⁢(tk)1−e−σ¯⁢(tk)⁢(tk−tk−1))⁢∏j=k+1n(1−σ⁢(tj)⁢e−σ¯⁢(tj)1−e−σ¯⁢(tj)⁢(tj−tj−1)).subscript𝑟𝑘𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗𝑘1𝑛1𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗1superscript𝑒¯𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗1r_{k}=(\sigma(t_{k})\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k})}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k})}% }(t_{k}-t_{k-1}))\prod_{j=k+1}^{n}(1-\sigma(t_{j})\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j}% )}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j})}}(t_{j}-t_{j-1})).italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_σ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_σ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) . (D.29)

For conditional generation cases where the generating sequence length l𝑙litalic_l is less than the dimension d𝑑ditalic_d, similar results hold. The only difference is that Nk∼Binomial⁢(l,rk)similar-tosubscript𝑁𝑘Binomial𝑙subscript𝑟𝑘N_{k}\sim\text{Binomial}(l,r_{k})italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Binomial ( italic_l , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Eq. D.22 changes to

E-NFEs⁢(n)=∑k=1n(1−(1−rk)l).E-NFEs𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛1superscript1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑙\text{E-NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(1-(1-r_{k})^{l}).E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - ( 1 - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (D.30)

Specifically, if we adopt a log-linear noise schedule and let tk=knsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑘𝑛t_{k}=\frac{k}{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG, according to Section D.4, the Euler method and Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping method are equivalent. In this case, Eq. D.27 simplifies to 1n1𝑛\frac{1}{n}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG. Substituting this result into Eq. D.22, we obtain

E-NFEs⁢(n)=∑k=1n(1−(1−1n)l)=n⁢(1−(1−1n)l).E-NFEs𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛1superscript11𝑛𝑙𝑛1superscript11𝑛𝑙\text{E-NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(1-(1-\frac{1}{n})^{l})=n(1-(1-\frac{1}{n})^{l}).E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - ( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_n ( 1 - ( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (D.31)

Appendix E Discussion for mean parameterization and RADD

Equivalence of modeling

Analogous to the x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT prediction in continuous state diffusion models, Austin et al. [20] and Campbell et al. [26] used the mean parameterization 𝝁θ⁢(𝒙t,t)subscript𝝁𝜃subscript𝒙𝑡𝑡{\bm{\mu}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t)bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) to learn the the reverse density p0|ti⁢(x0i|𝒙t)superscriptsubscript𝑝conditional0𝑡𝑖conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡p_{0|t}^{i}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), i=1⁢⋯⁢d𝑖1⋯𝑑i=1\cdots ditalic_i = 1 ⋯ italic_d. According to the analytic form of reverse distribution in Eq. D.8, letting s=0𝑠0s=0italic_s = 0, we have:

p0|ti⁢(x0i|𝒙t)={p0⁢(x0i|𝒙tUM),x0i≠[M],xti=[M],0,x0i=[M],xti=[M],δx0i⁢xti,xti≠[M].superscriptsubscript𝑝conditional0𝑡𝑖conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡casessubscript𝑝0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑡UMformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]M0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑖delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]Msubscript𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖delimited-[]Mp_{0|t}^{i}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\begin{cases}{p_{0}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}% ^{\textrm{UM}})},&x_{0}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],\\ 0,&x_{0}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],\\ \delta_{x_{0}^{i}x_{t}^{i}},&x_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}].\end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] . end_CELL end_ROW (E.1)

This shows that the mean prediction is equivalent to learning conditional distributions on clean data. In conjunction with our discussion in Section 3.1, the mean parameterization should be time-independent, denoted as 𝝁θ⁢(𝒙t)subscript𝝁𝜃subscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{\mu}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and is equivalent to our reparameterized 𝒄θ⁢(𝒙t)subscript𝒄𝜃subscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{c}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Empirical results He et al. [25] and Sahoo et al. [47], which demonstrate that the time-independent model 𝝁θ⁢(𝒙t)subscript𝝁𝜃subscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{\mu}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) performs well, also validate our theory.

Equivalence of training objectives

Shi et al. [42] proved that the training loss for score parameterization (i.e., DSE loss) and mean parameterization (i.e., negative ELBO loss) is equivalent.

Equivalence of sampling methods

Comparing our Section D.2 with Shi et al. [42], Sahoo et al. [47], it is evident that the Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping method for score parameterization is equivalent to the sampling method for mean prediction as follows:

qθ⁢(xs|xt)=p⁢(xs|xt,x0=μ⁢(xt))={Cat⁢(xs;xt),xt≠[M],Cat⁢(xs;1−αs1−αt⁢𝐞[M]+αs−αt1−αt⁢μ⁢(xt)),xt=[M].subscript𝑞𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑥𝑡𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥0𝜇subscript𝑥𝑡casesCatsubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡delimited-[]MCatsubscript𝑥𝑠1subscript𝛼𝑠1subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐞delimited-[]Msubscript𝛼𝑠subscript𝛼𝑡1subscript𝛼𝑡𝜇subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡delimited-[]Mq_{\theta}(x_{s}|x_{t})=p(x_{s}|x_{t},x_{0}=\mu(x_{t}))=\begin{cases}\textrm{% Cat}(x_{s};x_{t}),&x_{t}\neq[\textbf{M}],\\ \textrm{Cat}(x_{s};\frac{1-\alpha_{s}}{1-\alpha_{t}}\mathbf{e}_{[\textbf{M}]}+% \frac{\alpha_{s}-\alpha_{t}}{1-\alpha_{t}}\mu(x_{t})),&x_{t}=[\textbf{M}].\\ \end{cases}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_μ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = { start_ROW start_CELL Cat ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ [ M ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL Cat ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; divide start_ARG 1 - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ M ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_μ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ M ] . end_CELL end_ROW (E.2)

Here, αtsubscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the probability of a token remaining unmasked at time t𝑡titalic_t, which equals e−σ¯⁢(t)superscript𝑒¯𝜎𝑡e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for score parameterization. Therefore, Eq. E.2 and Eq. D.8 is equivalent.

Appendix F Algorithms for training and sampling

Appendix G Experimental details

G.1 Model details

We implemented our RADD model based on the SEDD architecture, an encoder-only transformer model [53, 54]. Our model incorporates rotary positional encoding [55] but excludes all parts related to time conditioning (i.e., TimeEmbedding, adaLN-zero block [56]). Instead, we added a softmax operation at the end of the neural network to ensure the output is a valid conditional distribution. Our modification resulted in a reduction of 7 million parameters, leading to an 8% decrease from the original 90 million non-embedding parameters of the SEDD small model.

G.2 Training details

We trained our RADD-DSE model following the configuration settings from [29]. The training configuration is as follows:

  • •

    Batch Size: 512

  • •

    Learning Rate: 3×10−43superscript1043\times 10^{-4}3 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

  • •

    Exponential Moving Average (EMA):0.9999

  • •

    Gradient Clipping: Gradient norm clipped to 1

  • •

    Warmup Schedule: Applied for the first 2500 iterations

  • •

    weight decay: 0

  • •

    dropout rate: 0.1

For the models RADD-t⁢-DCE𝑡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE, RADD-λ⁢-DCE𝜆-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_λ -DCE, and RADD-AO, we referenced the hyperparameters from [42]. The modifications included setting the weight decay to 0.03 and the dropout rate to 0.02. Due to limited computational resources, we did not conduct a hyperparameter search and ran experiments directly with these configurations. Further hyperparameter tuning may improve performance.

We trained on nodes of 32 V100 32G GPUs with float16 precision.

G.3 Unconditional Generation Details

For unconditional generation, we employed a log-linear noise schedule. As illustrated in Section 3.2, the Euler method and the Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping method are equivalent under this case. In practice, the implementation of the Euler method and the Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping method remains the same for RADD but differs for SEDD. So we measure the perplexity of SEDD by Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping method which performs slightly better while it suffices to measure the perplexity of RADD once.

The following procedures were used for generating samples:

  • •

    RADD Small: We generated 1024 samples to calculate the average value.

  • •

    SEDD Small: We utilized the results provided for steps less than 2048 and performed our evaluation at 4096 steps.

No annealing methods (e.g., top-p or top-k sampling) were applied in our sampling process.

G.4 Further evaluation of generative perplexity

Runtime Comparison

To assess inference efficiency, we measured the inference time on a single NVIDIA 4090 GPU with a batch size of 8, averaged over 1024 samples. The results are summarized in Table 3.

Across all sampling steps, the RADD model consistently required the shortest sampling time while maintaining similar perplexity levels to the SEDD model. Quantitatively, RADD achieved a speed-up of 2.5 to 3.5 times, as shown in Table 3. These findings align with the analysis of the E-NFEs in Fig. 2, validating the effectiveness of the RADD model and the caching strategy. They also demonstrate the practical implications of our Theorem 1.

Sampling as any-order autoregressive models

As outlined in Theorem 1, 𝒄θsubscript𝒄𝜃{\bm{c}}_{\theta}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be interpreted as a conditional distribution over clean data. One natural approach is to use this directly for generating samples, similar to any-order autoregressive models. However, there are d!𝑑d!italic_d ! possible ways to decompose the joint distribution into conditional distributions. We tested three representative cases:

  • •

    forward: p⁢(x1⁢⋯⁢xd)=∏k=1dp⁢(xk|x(<k))𝑝superscript𝑥1⋯superscript𝑥𝑑superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑑𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑥absent𝑘p(x^{1}\cdots x^{d})=\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{k}|x^{(<k)})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋯ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( < italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

  • •

    backward: p⁢(x1⁢⋯⁢xd)=∏k=1dp⁢(xk|x(>k))𝑝superscript𝑥1⋯superscript𝑥𝑑superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑑𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑥absent𝑘p(x^{1}\cdots x^{d})=\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{k}|x^{(>k)})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋯ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( > italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

  • •

    random: π∼Uπsimilar-to𝜋subscript𝑈𝜋\pi\sim U_{\pi}italic_π ∼ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p(x1⋯xd)=∏k=1dp(xπ⁢(k)|xπ(<k)p(x^{1}\cdots x^{d})=\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{\pi(k)}|x^{\pi(<k)}italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋯ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π ( < italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT)

The results are presented in Table 4. Perplexity was calculated as the average over 1024 samples. For the random case, we calculated the average perplexity across different randomly generated π𝜋\piitalic_π. Generally, we found that directly sampling from the conditional distribution resulted in higher perplexity compared to Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping or the Euler method with similar computational costs. Among the different decomposition orders, the forward order demonstrated the best performance.

Appendix H Additional experimental results

H.1 Additional samples

Additional unconditionally and conditionally generated text of RADD-t⁢-DCE𝑡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE and RADD-λ⁢-DCE𝜆-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_λ -DCE are reported in Figs. 3 to 6. All samples are generated with 1024 steps under a log-linear noise schedule.
